Then they hired a supervisor and racially profiled me from the minute she started working there. More than half of the clinic employees quit due to the unskilled ethic of management. I was 1 of 2 Hispanics working here in the South Holland location. My work spoke for his self when doctors where defending me and loved to work with me. I never understood why this supervisor never liked me other than me being Hispanic. I have came to her and talked to her professionally to help me understand why and she always gave me a bs excuse. Also they threw New commitments on me with not proper training and basically blamed me for everything even though I came to them with proper time to resolve everything. In all this company or at least in this office they go by racially profiling people and don’t care how good someone works if your not like them. I am disgusted with how this company’s direction is heading never work here!!!!!

job_title: Officer II in Oak Lawn, IL
pros: Great team, excellent leadership and people willing to go the extra mile. The leaders trust their officers to do their jobs and make decisions, & take input from the front line staff seriously and we all play a part in the decision making. The training is top-notch, there is a ton of experience in the department and there is a lot of room for advancement having so many hospitals in the system.  Leaders who actually care and listen and lead a team, good comradery and the working relationship between all of the clinical units is unreal!  A great Department, quality high-end equipment to do your job and your team and managers always have your back.
cons: The pay could be better.  yes we're not a sworn police department, but we operate like one and handle the same types of calls. I get it we can't be paid like a municipal department, but there needs to be a happy medium with the work and environment that is required and for better retention.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Downers Grove, IL
pros: The work/life balance is okay, you get a little over two weeks for each year for PTO. But this includes all the holidays that are enforced to everyone to take off.
cons: Benefits are expensive for being a healthcare company, you will always owe a balance for every doctor appointment, even if they are through Advocate. Pay is okay, I would say on the lower end of the range to be considered competitive, and the bonus is almost nothing. Systems that are worked with every day are very old fashioned, lots of paper to print and lots of scanning. Although, I hear this may be fixed soon. Little thank you's to employees have been taken away - group outings, free lunches, gifts, etc. The CEO is one of the highest paid in IL, but then the hospitals are told to cut back on medical supplies (plenty of articles on this are available online). Communication between HR and management to all other employees is almost non-existent.

job_title: Clinical Nurse Lead in Oak Lawn, IL
pros:
-CEO Jim Skogsbergh is a visionary leader that will bring Advocate Aurora Health to great places.
-401K 3% match if you put in 6%, also an 3% additional added in if you work >1000 hours in a year
-tuition reimbursement $5000-$7500
-VP-level executives across the system all took pay cuts in order to give COVID premium pay and hospital surge pay to front-line workers
-Good communication and weekly updates from system executive leadership
-A lot of opportunity to experience many different areas of nursing
-Security actually have firearms to protect patients and staff
-Very attentive and responsive CNO
cons:
-All Assistant Clinical Managers were rebranded (demoted) to RN Clinical Leads effectively taking away direct reports thus decreasing the ability to learn how to be an effective nurse leader
-100% Vesting for 401K match will take 5 years, each year it goes up by 20%
-Health insurance is just okay

job_title: Emergency Department Technician in Chicago, IL
pros: Working at Advocate allowed me to pursue further education to advance my career in medicine that I would not have been able to afford otherwise.  Their tuition reimbursement was critical in allowing me to finish pre-requisites for a graduate program, and they were very flexible in helping me work my full-time schedule around my classes. Benefits were very reasonable, and PTO accrued rapidly. When I left the company to get my Master's degree, I had more than a month of PTO left that I was able to cash out in a lump sum.
cons: The tuition reimbursement structure has shifted recently, now requiring a commitment to work for the company for a certain amount of time after receiving the tuition reimbursement. Additionally, pay can be slow to increase. There are also frequent "meetings that could have been emails", but this isn't a problem that is unique to this company.

review_title: First 90 days of employment at Advocate Aurora Health
job_title: Cetfid Medical Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: From my first 90 days of being employed with advocate health care, I've come across very friendly staff and team members.  All whom are very helpful and are there to answer any questions that you may have. Each clinical team member and PSR is there to help you and guide you.
cons: I've come across some things that I have  noticed that could work better in my clinic and with Advocate generally speaking.  Better communication with clinical staff and nurses. Making sure that every one is on the same page with patients.  PSRs need to communicate with the clinical staff when it comes to checking insurances and making sure insurance is correct and active. If a patient is passed the 15 min mark patient should be marked as a NO SHOW in less the Physicians  say otherwise. Lastly making sure exams rooms are stocked at ALL TIMES.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in West Allis, WI
pros: They offer tuition assistance.  Working here as a CNA will help me easily transition to a nurse external position and an RN after that.  I’m lucky to have a team of nurses and assistants that take care of each other.
cons: The pay is less than what I could make at local grocery stores.  I work on one of the more decently staffed floors and it’s still understaffed some of the time.  I also hear that raises are less than a dollar.  Orientation was ten shifts and then it’s trial by fire...for better or worse.  Many employees feel like cogs in a soulless machine.  Managers come and go every year, while trying “new” procedures and practices that have been tried and failed in the past.

job_title: Staff RN in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Generally the orientation  and onboarding process was very smooth.  Thank you for always having the coffee machines available.   Nurses don't sit much, thanks for all the breaks.
cons: The skills day, I wanted to pull my hair out.  No seasoned nurse should have to endure that day.  To be honest, thinking back to when I was a new nurse, I don't think it was effective instruction.  The only real hands on training was with the pumps.  The safe patient handling station is a total waste, all you do is look at the equipment only to go to a class and learn to use it on another day.  The central line dressing station, could not change a dressing as it would damage the manikin.  Try practice dressings on the back of a pie plate, otherwise that station offered little in "skill" development.

job_title: Trauma Coordinator in Elgin, IL
pros: Very high functioning health care system with amazing outcomes and patient satisfaction.  I was given a lot of opportunity to develop myself and  decide what was most important to me in my profession.  Lots of amazing mentors and leaders within the organization.  Competitive salary and benefits.  One of the largest healthcare organizations in the country.
cons: Lots of work as an administrator; work more with less.  Healthcare as a whole is a business, so sometimes it is hard to remember as a nurse that business and healthcare are now one in the same as a nurse.  Management is a little rough around the edges; productivity is difficult for front line staff to deal with.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Milwaukee, WI
pros:
Advancement in technologies
Typically good co-workers
Tuition reimbursement 
Other perks such as discounts on gym memberships, tickets for entertainment or travel
Depending on job, flexible hours
Some patients make everything worth it!
cons:
The Advocate “merger” has negatively impacted a significant amount of Aurora “team members” compared to those on the Advocate side. It’s extremely discouraging going to work every day not knowing if you will keep your job or not. Worst of all the  restructure hurt people that were dedicated to the organization for several years. 

Pay scale does NOT benefit people with years of service. Most newly hired people will begin at a higher starting rate than people who have been around for several years. Then, to give the long term caregiver a pay raise, it needs to be approved by HR which rarely happens, even with a legitimate  justification for the raise.

job_title: Supervisor in Green Bay, WI
pros: I have worked for other large healthcare organizations.  In meetings the other organizations would frequently stir up worry among the workers about what the competition is doing (i.e. Aurora).  This would cause people to be concerned for their jobs.  I have been with Aurora for almost 7 years now.  I have never, not even once, heard leadership stir up worry among staff about what the competition is doing.  It is encouraging to see Aurora Leadership focus on what they do best and continue to try to do it better!  This helps caregivers focus on what's important...patient care, not useless competition that they can't do anything about anyway.  Great job Aurora!!!
cons: Because of its size, sometimes when changes are made it takes time for those changes to get communicated to everyone.  But that's part of being big.

review_title: Used to love my job, not anymore
job_title: Registered Nurse in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Flexible schedule, clinic job, good hours
cons: I have worked here almost 10 years and the morale is the worst it's ever been at my office. Many RNs are leaving because you can't move up on the payscale (I am not even to the midpoint on our payscale after 10 years). More and more responsibilities are being added without any more compensation or staffing. I'm actively looking for new jobs as are all the nurses in my department. Hasn't been good for morale since the Advocate Aurora merger.

job_title: Nurse Practitioner in Park Ridge, IL
pros: Great learning environment, CME reimbursement for full-time employees up to $1400 per year. Over my 13+ years with the company I stayed because I feel like on the part of the family, although many nurses close to retirement are leaving for other jobs a lot of colleagues are seeking new opportunities.  There are definitely growth opportunities within the company for employees wanting to grow professionally and educationally.
cons: As a fairly new nurse practitioner I noticed that Walgreens APNs are offered starting hourly rate $10 more than hospital-based or outpatient clinic AMG APNs. Salary for middle level providers it’s not competitive. Although it’s advertised differently. Personally I think that advocate pays more Walgreens APN due to union status and hospitals APN do not get that benefit.

review_title: It IS possible to work for an organization lets you have it all: work life balance, great pay, excellent benefits
job_title: Human Resources/Onboarding Coordinator in Normal, IL
pros: Work/Life Balance, excellent benefits, great pay - and merit-based increases ev. year when you rank "Meets Expectations" or higher on performance review.  Endless opportunities for professional growth.
cons: Sometimes - as is true for most health care organizations - when patient census is low, team members on that unit may be flexed for the day, and would need to use any banked PTO they have to cover it, or else lose out on that day's pay.

review_title: Positive culture, happy employees, great patient experience
job_title: RN, Bsn in Charlotte, NC
pros: I moved to Aurora from another Green Bay health system because of a great patient experience a family member received at Aurora Baycare Medical Center. I have seen evidence of innovation & authenticity.  Positive culture has been seen and felt from my recruitment experience through orientation and this continues in my department.
cons: When I accepted the position, the retirement benefits were better than my previous employer - however, with the 2020 changes this is no longer the case (401K match decreased from 4.5 to 3).  I am also disappointed that the HSA option for health care savings has been eliminated.

review_title: Great culture, great people, and overall a great place to work!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Green Bay, WI
pros: I love Aurora. I have worked at Aurora (now Advocate Aurora Health) for over 15 years. I have five family members who also work for Aurora. I love the people who I work with. Everyone truly lives the Advocate Aurora Health's mission on a daily basis,  and that is to help people live well through compassion, excellence and respect.
cons: Once in a position it's quite difficult to move up to the pay that matches your experience and performance. It is frustrating that compensation for loyal high preforming employees does not match the rate in which pay increases for newly hired people just offered a position.

job_title: SRCO Revenue Employee in Oakbrook Terrace, IL
pros: Flex start time ,casual dress, good tuition reimbursement program
cons: Unqualified management,  micro managers,  chained to the chair,  productivity driven, horrible PTO program, no advancement for seasoned knowledgeable employees. Too much hiring of family members and friends

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Charlotte, NC
pros: Love working with the Patients and interacting, love how fast pace VLCC is, Days fly by.
cons: With the fast pace environment, feel terrible at times when on the phone due to excessive calls and patient standing in front of you to check in or let you know they are back down for treatment.  Feels like phone rings non stop and that's the last thing Patient wants to hear.   It's very hard for patient to tell if on phone or not.  Scheduling can be a challenge as each doctor does things different verses consistent with multiple appointments.

review_title: They cut costs any way they can
job_title: Medical Technologist in Fort Mill, SC
pros: Competitive pay.  They pay me more than I was offered at University of Chicago for the same position.
cons: Even before the merger they were cutting costs any way they could.  Housekeeping was decimated once the unions started making noise, an obvious tactic to keep people in line.  Same goes with cafeteria staff.  Except for day shift, there is barely anything to offer after 2 pm so the evening and midnight shifts had best bring their own food.  Also, the insurance packages they offer are so weak that I get my coverage from my husband's job instead.

job_title: Cash Applications in Fort Mill, SC
pros:
Safe work environment
Flexible scheduling
Opportunity for growth
cons:
Job Titles/Descriptions: should to be updated to reflect actual work being performed; many of them haven't been updated in the last 6-10 years.

Compensation:  pay  upon hire for most of the positions are below the WI median wage for many or the positions. When transferring to a new position you shouldn't have your merit taken away for work that you have done. The transfer should be lateral unless your taking a positions as a lead, supervisor, or manager.

Training :not the worst but definitely needs improvement

Employee perks: there should be more programs offered to employees for drug, verbal/physical abuse, mental health, disabilities, etc. 

Human Resources: I shouldn't have to create a case online in order to speak with Human resource personnel.

review_title: South Shore location: Overall good place to work
job_title: Medical Technologist in Green Bay, WI
pros: The whole staff was very friendly and worked with you. The lab is small and so you get to know everyone that works there. I worked first shift and we rotated start times, earliest being 6 am and latest being 8 am. You are assigned an area in the lab each day and that is where you work.
cons: The lab was short staffed and there would be days where we didn't have the right number of people to work so the lead would have to help out in addition to doing their job. Management was more concerned about the numbers then the opinion of the staff and helping them out. It felt as though if we could get the work done with the number of people we had they didn't really push for more positions or help.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Staff gets along well. Staff assists with one another the best we can
cons: There is no advancement, employees are not respected, listened to and good work is NEVER noticed. Instead, employees have tons of excess work thrown on them to save a buck. Each staff member does the work of three employees because Advocate will not hire new associates to cover the deficit. Management is a bit of a mess from the top down.  There is absolutely no room for advancement unless you know someone from the top.

review_title: Aurora health is a great place to work
job_title: Acl Courier in Chicago, IL
pros: People are so nice and helpful, benefits are very nice. Been employed for a month and so far has been an amazing place to work with amazing people to work with.
cons: In the beginning was very overwhelming with all that had to be done in a short period of time, with setting up emails, and setting up appointments, email references and passwords, maybe because I’m not the most computer savvy person but I figured it out and got thru the process and would say it was well worth the trouble and hassle once I accomplished all that had to be done.

review_title: A little of what I feel.
job_title: Chef in Milwaukee, WI
pros:
There are job opportunities everywhere.
The pay is much higher here than at other places in the same field.
The commute is very easy.
The company is very visible in the community. They are on TV, at social events and charities doing positive things.
There are opportunities to meet a lot of people.
cons:
It's hard to terminate some team members who are underperforming and just skating by, doing the very minimum to keep getting a paycheck.
Some team members in leadership roles have been here 10+ years and seem to lack motivation to help newer team members or have a positive attitude at doing their job.
The medical insurance could be better.
The café foods could have healthier choices.

job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Hazel Crest, IL
pros: I have been with Advocate for quite some time.  I have seen them stay consistent in the quality of care they want to give our patients. On the employee stand point, I feel that Advocate cares about the people that help make this place run. I think leadership is pretty clear on the direction this organization is making. They are and have been very open and honest in the messaging to employees.
cons: Advocate has been a company of many changes and all have been for the better, however I don't think leadership understands the timing and communication that is necessary to roll out new processes.  I think our leaders here may have the communication just not rolling in out timely to staff. We always seem to have that issue.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Wauwatosa, WI
pros: Several different programs and levels of care to meet different patient needs;  Great resource for helping patients with mental health and addiction issues get the treatment and support you need; Safety is being highlighted on campus for both caregivers and patients;  there have been several projects in the past year to help improve facilities on an already campus;  Definitely a place where you can make a difference; It's great to be a part of a large medical system and options to move around Aurora Behavioral Health Systems and Aurora Healthcare as a whole
cons: Hiring and on boarding process can take a while; Sometimes different groups feel isolated - caregivers might not see other levels of care or other programs very much unless you get on a campus wide committee - but there are offerings for those

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Milwaukee, WI
pros: An amazing place to work and caring and inclusive environment  prior to the merger.
cons: It feels like the other organization is taking over based on the newly created Executive leadership team. The organizational structure at many functions is still in flux creating uncertainty and lack of motivation. No transparency and or asking for input on major decisions, which are just rolled from top down. Advocate people are promoted at the expense of Aurora’s employees who are being knocked down a level or let go. Not a good time to join now.

job_title: Emergency Department Technician in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Love almost everyone I work with. Managers try their best to accommodate given the circumstances with how upper management is.  Overall very friendly management.
cons: Upper management does not seem to listen to those that actually work in the ED. Staffing and bed issues have gotten bad where we might only have 2 open beds in the ED that are not inpatient. During night shift providers will be picking up 15 patients each or refuse to pick up new patients despite them having rooms. That is more a provider staffing issue.  Pay and scheduling is lackluster. Some people will be working eight days in a row consistently and I wish pay was more for the things I deal with.

job_title: Registered Nurse in West Allis, WI
pros: I love my fellow workers, including all the doctors that frequent in the OR.  The staff is pleasant and great to work with.  I am able to help in several roles here which looks great on the resume, so that is a plus.  Examples would be Charge RN, coordinator and now educator.  We, meaning the staff, acknowledge each other on jobs well done day to day.
cons: Senior leadership is constantly in meetings, which is understandable, but when the manager is not present in our department day to day, we all have issues with that. job_title: Cardiovascular Technologist in Oak Lawn, IL
pros: Experience in a fast paced trauma center looks good on a resume. They love new grads and pay medium wages.

You will be VERY understaffed and overworked making medium level pay not worth the stress. Lunches , raises and bonuses are non existent unless you are upper management and taken out of pay automatically.  Your opinions do not count and will be bullied by staff and management if you are not like minded. Insurance is crazy expensive until you've been there at least 10 yrs. Seniority is not looked at as loyalty to the company and once you hit a moderate livable wage , you will be harrassed, bullied and written up for things that never happened, then fired or forced to quit for a lower wage replacement of you. Do your research especially Christ  in Oak Lawn and choose wisely when considering employment there. The key is dont take less than you are worth . They will give no raises or bonuses and nickle and dime your retirement . If they give you anything,  they WILL find a way to get it back while sucking the life out of you ! If your looking for a long term career this is not your choice! Short term looks great and will help you get your foot into a more honest and reputable company but beware ! Do not invest much time  in advocate. They are businesses and upper management focused. You are just a number and very disposable. I wouldn't take my hamster there let alone allow a loved one to be cared for there. I was there 20 plus years. It has gone downhill and self destructed in the last 10 with greed definitely running the show. It's a business without concern for the actual patients in mind.
